description.narrative: Preventing and Countering Corruption in Papua New Guinea by support the National Anti-Corruption Plan of Action (NACPA) 2020-2025 to implement the PNG National Anti-Corruption Strategy (NACS) 2010-2030.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Outcome 1: NACPA progressively implemented and monitored, including through law reforms Indicator - Internal public service anti-corruption processes working more effectively to prevent and expose corruption.
Outcome 4 - Network of community stakeholders in support of anti-corruption efforts mobilized. Indicator - More civic actors engaged in the fight against corruption

comment.narrative:
Outcome 1: NACPA progressively implemented and monitored, including through law reform. Baseline: World Bank corruption indicator = -0.91 Target: Improvement in World Bank corruption indicators
Outcome 4 - Network of community stakeholders in support of anti-corruption efforts mobilized. Baseline: TIPNG active but civil society scattered otherwise Target: : 5 civil society partners actively working on AC initiatives

Output 1.1: NACPA Secretariat supported to implement NACPA, including M&E and reporting requirements (NACPA POW#8) Target 1: Complete NACPA framework under implementation Target 2: PMNEC, TWG, sectoral groups meeting regularly to undertake effective oversight of NACPA implementation
Activity 1.1.1 - Technical assistance (TA) provided to PMNEC and NACPA members to implement NACPA + undertake ongoing coordination and oversight of implementation efforts.
Target for 2022: 2 workshops
% Target for 2022: 50 % Full project target: 4 workshops
Activity 1.1.2 - TA and capacity development support provided to PMNEC and NACPA members to design M&E framework and put in place necessary reporting processes, infrastructure, and well-capacitated reporting personnel.
Target for 2022: 2 workshops
% Target for 2022: 50 % Full project target: 4 workshops
Activity 1.1.3 - A TA provided to PMNEC Governance Branch to strengthen NEC oversight of “bureaucratic accountability” (POW#8)
Target for 2022: 1 Reporting package developed
% Target for 2022: 100 % Full project target: 1 Reporting package developed
Activity 1.1.4 - TA provided to produce and publish regular NACPA progress reports
Target for 2022: 3 progress workshops
% Target for 2022: 50 % Full project target: 6 progress workshops

Output 1.1: NACPA Secretariat supported to implement NACPA, including M&E and reporting requirements (NACPA POW#8) Target1: Complete NACPA framework under implementation Target2: PMNEC, TWG, sectoral groups meeting regularly to undertake effective oversight of NACPA implementation
Output 1.2: Key anti-corruption law reforms progressed (NACPA POW#1) Target1: FOI law passed Target2: PNG laws updated to implement UNCAC
Output 1.3: Guidelines and processes for new legal frameworks designed and implemented (NACPA POW#7) Target1: Supporting Regulations and guidelines produced Target2: Public servants and govt agencies complying with their duties under new regimes
Output 1.4: Corruption risk assessments completed and strategies designed in response (NACPA POW#3) Target: 10 agencies/units assessed
Output 1.5: Key anti-corruption institutions supported to implement their NACPA priorities in a coordinated and efficient manner (NACPA POW#2) Target: 5
Output 4.1: Non-state actors supported to undertake AC education, awareness and reporting Target1: 12 activities (approx. 4 per year) Target2: At least 10 major AC media stories/discussions related to Project support
Output 4.2: Catalytic small grant funding provided to support non-government and community anti-corruption initiatives Target: At least 10 grants

Output 1.1
PNG, as a State party to the UNCAC, is currently undergoing its second review cycle as part of the mechanism for the review of implementation of UNCAC (UNCAC Implementation Review Mechanism). This cycle focuses on UNCAC Chapters II (Preventive measures) and V (Asset recovery). UNODC is the UNCAC Secretariat and is supporting PNG’s review. The reviewers are from Burundi and Kyrgyzstan. Both the Government of PNG and the reviewers, with UNODC, have agreed on the country visit taking place during the week of 9 May 2022.
PNG, as one of 18 Pacific Islands Forum Leaders, further adopted the Teieniwa Vision (Pacific Unity Against Corruption) as the regional anti-corruption roadmap at the Leaders Forum in February 2021. The Teieniwa Vision, inter alia, includes development and review of the National Anti-Corruption Strategies and policies, and implementation arrangements, including within the national plans, through a participatory process which includes civil society, youth, private sector, Parliamentarians, media and other stakeholders.
The coordination meeting with the representatives of the key government partner organizations was held in November 2021, to discuss needs, priorities and activities for 2022.
Output 1.2 A joint UNODC-UNDP submission on PNG’s draft National Right to Information (RTI) Policy (2020-2030) was submitted on 28 October 2021. This submission responds to the consultation draft shared on the website of the Ministry for Information and Communication Technology and was at the request of the FOI Technical Working Group Chair, Mr. Flierl Shongol. This was on the back of a joint UNODC-UNDP webinar on right to information under the United Nations Pacific Regional Anti-Corruption (UN-PRAC) Project in 2020 that was held for members of the FOI Technical Working Group under the PNG Open Government Partnership (OPG) National Action Plan. It included FOI experts from the RTI Unit of Vanuatu, Office of the New Zealand Ombudsman and Office of the Australian Information Commissioner.
The RTI Policy will inform the process of drafting the FOI Bill which is among 10 key legal reforms identified and prioritized by the PNG Government and included in the NAPCA Programme of Work 1 - Legislative and Policy Framework. It is anticipated that the Project will focus on supporting finalization and implementation of the RTI Policy in late 2021 and early 2022, as the PNG national election in June 2022 make it unlikely that FOI legislation will be tabled and enacted until the new Parliament is elected and in place.
Output 1.3:
The implementation of the current Whistleblower Protection Act might be challenging due to the above-mentioned loopholes (see the details under the Output 1.2). That said, the Organic Law on the ICAC might provide more comprehensive protection of whistleblowers than the Whistleblower Protection Act. Read together, work can therefore still proceed to start progressing implementation of a whistleblower protection regime. In November 2021, the additional publication relevant to PNG was released by UN-PRAC, titled Whistle-blower Protections and Corruption Reporting in Pacific Island Countries. It includes a comprehensive review of the PNG Whistleblower Act 2020 that will inform further support to the implementation of the whistleblower protection legislation.
Output 1.4 The UNDP PNG Anti-Corruption Adviser conducted an initial discussion with UN-PRAC team to identify potential synergies amongst both projects, as UN-PRAC is also progressing work to support anti-corruption risk assessments and mitigation plans in Solomon Islands. This has, inter alia, included the knowledge product on corruption risks in public procurement. The Consultant working with Solomon Islands has been recruited by the UNDP PNG team to support this work.
Output 1.5 The establishment of the ICAC Appointment and Oversight Committees and the appointment process of the ICAC Commissioners was supported by the AC Project upon request of the DJAG and the ICAC Chairman. Fit and Proper Test had been developed for the appointment of the Commissioners and the Codes of Conduct for Appointment Committee and Oversight Committee was drafted upon request.
Output 4.1 AC team held two meetings with TI PNG as a key project non-governmental partner for public education and anti-corruption awareness activities. The discussions were focused mainly on the legal reform (challenges related to the ICAC legislation; developments related to the FOI Bill drafting and other FOI related support), and other key areas of the current TI PNG work (i.e. support to the Government, awareness activities, etc.). TI PNG has expressed their general interest to collaborate with UNDP in the project activities. UNDP has also started mapping potential NGO partners, including amongst youth groups, the private sector and the media.
To effectively engage civic sector actors not only from Port Moresby but also from the provinces, UNDP has started mapping anti-corruption actors across PNG during the reporting period. This will be an ongoing activity and UNDP will continue the mapping jointly with UNODC, based on the UN-PRAC project previous work on this area. The UNDP Anti-Corruption Adviser is seeking meetings with potential NGO partners, but has been impeded by the inability to travel in-country.
The International Anti-Corruption Day on 9 December was marked by the joint UNDP and UNODC visibility/awareness activity. Two anti-corruption posters with specific focus on PNG were developed by both teams and widely shared through the social media, and the public statement by UN Resident Coordinator a.i. was published.
Output 4.2 UNDP has started the recruitment process for the national staff who will support process of development of the procedures and implementation of these activities. UNDP initiated discussion with UN-PRAC project team to identify potential synergies amongst both projects, including in relation to the UN-PRAC team’s experience with accountable small grant funding to their own Pacific partners in order to ensure this Project can benefit from their lessons learned and good practice.
